stem: An unidentified client is brought to the ED following a major explosion. He is unconscious and has a life-threatening abdominal hemorrhage. Based on the documentation in the Trauma Resuscitation & Legal Surrogate Log tab, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely legal status, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Emergency surgery required without formal consent.
Background: Mass casualty victim. No ID found.
Assessment: Hemoglobin 5.1. BP 62/40. Active intra-abdominal pulsatile bleeding seen on FAST exam.
Recommendation: Immediate surgical exploration under emergency exception.

tabs.title: Legal & Surrogate Status
tabs.content:
CategoryResultAction Required
Patient NameJohn Doe #42N/A
CompetencyNone (Comatose)Assumed incapacity
Next of KinUnable to locateContinue search
Legal PrivilegeEmergency ExceptionApplies to life/limb

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 62/40, HR 142, RR 30. SpO2 90% on 15L. Client is in profound shock.

conditionOptions.text: Delayed Care pending Legal Guardian appointment

actionOptions.text: Proceed with emergency surgery and blood transfusion immediately
Document the physician's assessment of 'Life-Threat' in the medical record
Wait for a hospital administrator to sign as the temporary surrogate
Hold the surgery until a court-appointed advocate can be reached

parameterOptions.text: Hemodynamic stability and source-control of the hemorrhage
Continued efforts to identify the client and locate next of kin
Daily measurement of fasting serum glucose
Presence of a positive Babinski sign

rationale.correct: This is a case of the Emergency Exception (c2), also known as Implied Consent. In life-threatening emergencies where the patient is incapacitated and no surrogate is available, consent is legally implied because a reasonable person would want life-saving help. The nurse should facilitate immediate care (a1) and ensure the medical necessity is clearly documented (a2). Future efforts must continue to identify the person (p2) while managing their immediate physiological collapse (p1).
clinicalPearls: Emergency Exception applies to: Loss of life, loss of limb, or loss of an organ.
Administrative signatures are NOT required for true emergencies; clinical necessity is the legal standard.
The 'Doctrine of Implied Consent' is a protective shield for both the patient (getting help) and the provider (legal protection).

questionTrap.trap: Thinking you need two doctors to sign before saving a life.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: While some hospitals have a 'Two-Physician' rule for *major* elective-emergencies, in a true 'bleeding out' trauma situation, the law supports immediate action by anyone qualified. Don't let paperwork stall a pulse.
